content:
1. Bacteria are:

a. Virus
b. Pathogen
c. Microorganism
d. Non-pathogen
e. Fomite

2. A microorganism that causes disease is a:

a. Vector
b. Pathogen
c. Host
d. Bacteria
e. Parasite

3. Which agar is normally used when culture Neisseria Gonorrhea

a. Blood agar
b. Chocolate agar
c. Thayer- Martin agar
d. All of the above

4. Escherichia coli normally resides in the

a. Vagina
b. Urinary tract
 
c. Intestinal tract
d. Stomach
e. Eye

5. Which factor does not help a microorganism grow?

a. Darkness
b. Proper nutrition
c. Moisture
d. 7.1 pH
e. 4-5 pH

6. Which factor would interfere with the growth of a pathogen?

a. Appropriate oxygen and/or carbon dioxide
b. Light
c. Moisture
d. Acidic pH
e. Two of the above
7. What term describes a microorganism that requires oxygen to grow?

a. Microaerophiles
b. Thermolabile
c. Facultative anaerobe
d. Aerobe
e. Cryophile
8. The ‘optimum growth temperature’ is defined as:

a. 37oC or body temperature
b. The temperature at which microorganism grows best
c. Room temperature
d. Temperature that reduces number of pathogens
e. Refrigerator temperatures

9. The time period when symptoms have subsided, and the patient is regaining health is the:

a. Prodromal period
b. Incubation period
c. Decline period
d. Acute period
e. Convalescent period
 
10. List 2 specimens an MLA can collect according to the Specimen Collection Centre Act.

a. 
b. 

11. List 3 general guidelines to properly collect a microbiological specimen.

a. 
b. 
c. 

12. Throat swabs are collected to diagnose:

a. Herpes
b. Gangrene
c. Streptococcus
d. Typhoid fever
e. Gastroenteritis

13. The source of the specimen should be indicated on a swab for C&S to:

a. Assist the lab staff for billing purposes
b. Alert the lab staff that the swab is potentially hazardous
c. Determine of the swab is set up STAT
d. Assist in the selection of the plating media
e. Ensure that swabs do not get mixed up

14. Activated charcoal in transport medium will:

a. Inhibit growth of non-pathogens
b. Help maintain a neutral pH by neutralizing fatty acids and absorbing toxic substances
c. Maintain aerobic conditions
d. Keep the specimen from drying out

15. Which procedure is used to collect urine for C&S?

a. Clean catch MSU
b. Catheterization
c. Supra-public aspiration
d. Pediatric urine bag
e. All of the above

16. Which statement is false when giving instructions to collect a clean catch MSU?

a. An antiseptic cleanser must be used
 
b. Male patients must pull back the foreskin and cleanse the tip of penis
c. Female patients must cleanse from front to back
d. The first part of the urine is voided into the toilet; the next part is collected
e. None of the above

17. A Cutaneous mycosis is collected by performing a:

a. Gram stain
b. Skin scraping
c. Fecal concentration
d. Wet mount preparation
e. Venipuncture using culture tubes

18. Septicemia is detected by collecting:

a. Feces
b. Urine
c. Blood
d. CFS
e. Genital swab

19. Blood culture collection does not require:

a. That the specimen is collected first before all other tubes
b. Special cleansing with iodine and alcohol
c. An anaerobic and aerobic collection
d. The specimens to be kept at room temperature until they are incubated
e. An arterial specimen
20. Which statement is false regarding collecting a stool specimen for C&S?

a. A wide mouth sterile container must be used
b. A special diet must be followed several days prior to collection
c. Stool must not be contaminated with urine, toilet water, or toilet paper
d. The specimen is brought to the lab as soon as possible or kept refrigerated
e. The patient must label the specimen with date and time of collection

21. A specimen for pinworm testing is collected:

a. By a physician only
b. At the laboratory
c. Four days prior to antibiotic therapy
d. First thing in the morning before a bowel movement
e. Late at night after a bowel movement
 
22. What container is required for pinworm exam?

a. Sterile wide-mouth jar
b. Large metal can
c. Scotch tape/glass slide or sticky paddle
d. Jar containing SAF fluid
e. Swab containing Amies clear transport media

23. Cocci are:

a. Round is shape
b. A form of bacillus
c. Rod shaped
d. Always found is pairs
e. A category of microorganism

24. ‘Pyogenic’ means producing:

a. Pneumonia
b. Cough in the chest
c. Pus
d. Fever
e. Toxins

25. ‘Pyrogenic’ means producing:

a. Pneumonia
b. Cough in the chest
c. Pus
d. Fever
e. Toxins
26. Staphylococci:

a. Are arranged in pairs
b. Are pus producers
c. Are responsible for veneral disease
d. Are arranged in chains
e. Two of the above

27. Staphylococcus aureus causes everything except:

a. Boils
b. Wound infections
c. Meningitis
 
d. Abscesses
e. UTI

28. Streptococci are:

a. A form of diplococcic
b. Pyrogenic
c. Found in clusters
d. Are in chain formation
e. Two of the above

29. Which agar is used to culture Lactose fermenter Bacteria?

a. Blood agar
b. MacConkey agar
c. Colombia agar
d. Thayer-Martin agar
e. All agars

30. Which body fluid is collected to detect septicemia?

a. Urine
b. Blood
c. Sputum
d. CFS
e. Feces

31. This microorganism causes throat infection:

a. E. coli
b. Salmonella species
c. Streptococcus
d. Clostridium botulinum
e. All of the above might cause throat infection
32. Group A Streptococci cause:

a. Glomerulonephritis
b. Salmonella food poisoning
c. Rheumatic fever
d. Tuberculosis
e. ‘a’ and ‘c’ only

33. Some bacteria form a hard-protective covering resistant to heat and chemicals called a:
 

a. Scab
b. Cyst
c. Shell
d. Capsule
e. Spore
34. Bacilli may be:

a. A form of fungus
b. Round
c. Spore formers
d. All motile
e. None of the above

35. Blood agar media is:

a. Universal
b. Enriched
c. 5% sheep blood
d. Can show hemolytic activities
e. All of the above

36. Cylindrical shaped bacteria that have a lot of flexibility and movement are:

a. Spirochetes
b. Streptococci
c. Vibrios
d. Bacilli
e. Staphylococci

37. Bacteria that resemble a comma are:

a. Spirochetes
b. Streptococci
c. Vibrio
d. Spirillum
e. Staphylococci
38. What body fluid is collected to detect Neisseria meningitides?

a. Sputum
b. Blood
c. CSF
 
d. Vaginal/urethral
e. Two of the above

39. What organisms cause Gonorrhea? 
40. What specimen is submitted for testing? 
41. What organisms often cause Gastroenteritis? 
42. What specimen is submitted for testing? 
43. What organism causes syphilis? 
44. What specimen is submitted for testing? 

45. On a microscope, what adjusts the amount of light coming into the lens system?

a. Ocular
b. Revolving nosepiece
c. Objectives
d. Stage
e. Diaphragm

46. What is the total magnification of the oil immersion objectives and a 10X ocular?

a. 10X
b. 100X
c. 430X
d. 450X
e. 1000X

47. Which objective allows the largest field of vision?

a. Scanning objective
b. Low power objective
c. Medium power objective
d. High-dry objective
e. Oil immersion objective

48. Which is not done when a microscope is put away after use?

a. Remove the slide from the stage
b. Clean all the glass pieces of the microscope with lens paper and alcohol
c. Unplug the microscope
d. Turn off the light
e. Put on the dust cover
